newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Surprise rate cut to help Taiwan bourse - analysts.
newsitem.headline: Surprise rate cut to help Taiwan bourse - analysts.

text.p: A surprise rate cut by Taiwan's central bank is likely to boost the island's slow stock market bathed in recent uncertain Taiwan-China relations, securities analysts said on Friday.
Central bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong announced at a hastily arranged news conference that the bank was cutting banks' reserve requirements by up to 0.5 percentage point, effective on Saturday.
The market had been hoping for a rate cut, though analysts said they had not expected it before the central bank's September 12 board meeting.
"This is a surprise, and a good one," said George Hou, manager at Jardine Fleming.
"We should soon see gains in financial and construction shares. No matter how much the cut will help the economy, the stock market will be benefited first," he said.
Sheu said new reductions in reserve requirements would pump an additional T$25 billion into the island's sluggish economy.
"By releasing the funds, liquidity in the banking system will be loosened. That will lower costs for banks," Sheu said.
Analysts expected interest to increase in construction firms, now in the sixth year of a severe sectoral recession.
Recovery in the construction industry has been widely expected since the government vowed to speed up public works.
"After banks follow suit to cut rates, which is likely, the money will go into domestic investments or the stock market," said Benjamin Chen, branch manager of BZW Securities Taiwan.
Taiwan's stock market has been moving narrowly amid concerns over Taiwan-China relations.
China set rules on direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait earlier this week, boosting investor sentiment.
Taipei, saying Beijing's rules were mingled with political issues, still bans direct shipping links with China and was not expected to move quickly on the proposal.
On Friday, the stock market's weighted index closed up 39.40 points or 0.64 percent at 6,200.22.
Many players were adopting a wait-and-see attitude.

"The important thing is that the central bank promised a loose monetary policy to help the economy. The stock market will be happy to know that the promise is still valid," said Ben Lee, senior analyst at Normura Securities.
"The economy won't recover immediately, but the rate cut will at least prevent the economy from worsening," Jardine Fleming's Hou said.
